newsitem.title: GERMANY: SAP surges as dollar boosts Q1 profit.
newsitem.headline: SAP surges as dollar boosts Q1 profit.

text.p: Shares in German business software group SAP AG jumped on Tuesday after it said the strength of the dollar and a number of large new contracts led to sharp increases in its first quarter sales and earnings.
The company said in a regulatory statement that sales in the first quarter surged 49 percent to 1.032 billion marks and pre-tax profits jumped 54 percent to 181 million marks.
Currency movements, notably the recent rise of the dollar to 37-month highs against the mark, added 55 million marks to revenues, it later calculated.
SAP's DAX-30-quoted preference stock jumped to a new high of 303.50 marks after the figures, later settling back to 300 marks, still 7.10 marks or 2.5 percent up on the day.
Dealers said the market had been expecting pre-tax profit in the region of 155 million marks on sales of 920 million. "SAP was a complete surprise," said one.

SAP nonetheless stuck to its earlier forecast that sales would rise in the full year by some 25-30 percent. chairman Dietmar Hopp warned that sales growth could slow somewhat from the first quarter's pace.
"Due to the high comparison figures from last year, especially in the fourth quarter, we expect for the year as a whole a flattening of sales growth," Hopp said.
Strong orders from customers in the U.S., South Africa, India and France were largely behind the first quarter revenue gain, SAP noted.
